paragraph.content: provide for other means (in addition to publication in the Gazette) for making those places or areas known to the public. (Replaced 78 of 1999 s. 7)

section.name: s83B
section.heading: Commissioner for Transport may set aside streets for hawking purposes

subsection.content: No person shall hawk in any street except in accordance with a licence issued under regulations made under section 83A. (Replaced 28 of 1973 s. 2)
Any person who contravenes subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence. (Amended 28 of 1973 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner for Transport may from time to time, after consultation with the Authority and the Commissioner of Police, declare in writing that the whole or any part of a street may be set aside to be used for hawking purposes, and shall give notice of any such declaration—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by publishing it in one issue of the Gazette;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by publishing it in 3 consecutive issues of at least one English language newspaper and one Chinese language newspaper;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by causing copies of it to be exhibited in one or more conspicuous places in or in the immediate vicinity of the street.

subsection.leadIn: On the requirements of subsection (4) being satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Authority may allocate pitches in the street to hawkers (other than itinerant hawkers) licensed under regulations made pursuant to section 83A, subject to such conditions as may be specified by the Authority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Commissioner for Transport may, if he thinks necessary, by further notice in the Gazette, order that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the street be closed to vehicular traffic; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the street be closed to vehicular traffic travelling in such direction as he specifies in the notice,

paragraph.continued: either at all times or at such times as he specifies in the notice.

subsection.content: On making an order under subsection (5)(b), the Commissioner for Transport shall cause to be erected pursuant to the Road Traffic Ordinance (Cap. 374) at each entrance to the street appropriate signs indicating the closure in accordance with the order.

No action shall lie against the Government, the Commissioner for Transport, the Authority, or any public officer by reason only of the exercise of the powers conferred by this section. (Amended 59 of 2000 s. 3)
Where under subsection (4) only part of a street is set aside, every reference in this section to the street (街道) shall be construed as meaning the part of the street so set aside.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Power of authorized public officers to arrest in certain cases

subsection.content: Any public officer authorized in writing in that behalf by the Authority may arrest without warrant any person whom he may reasonably suspect of being guilty of any scheduled offence.
If any person forcibly resists the endeavour of any such officer to arrest him or attempts to evade the arrest, such officer may use all means necessary to effect the arrest.

If any such officer who is in pursuit of any person to be arrested has reason to believe that such person has entered into or is in any place, the person residing in or in charge of such place shall on demand of such officer allow him free ingress thereto and afford reasonable facilities for search therein for such person.
The Chief Executive in Council may by order amend, or add any enactment to or delete any enactment from, the First Schedule. (Amended 59 of 2000 s. 3)

section.name: s85
section.heading: Procedure for dealing with arrested person, etc.

subsection.content: Any person (hereinafter referred to as an arrested person) who is arrested under section 84(1) by a public officer shall forthwith be taken to the nearest police station or given into the custody of a police officer. (Amended 77 of 1979 s. 2)
Whenever an arrested person is brought to the police station the provisions of section 52 of the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232) shall apply.
Whenever an arrested person is given into the custody of a police officer, the provisions of sections 51 and 52 of the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232) shall apply.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Seizure of hawker equipment and commodities from alleged offenders

subsection.content: A public officer authorized in writing by the Authority for the purposes of this section or a police officer may seize any equipment or commodity in respect of which he has reason to believe that a hawker offence has been committed, and may cause such equipment or commodity to be removed to and kept at the risk of its owner at a Government depot or police station, or any other place approved by the Authority, pending its disposal under this Part. (Amended 28 of 1973 s. 3)
Any commodity of a perishable nature seized under subsection (1) may immediately be disposed of by the Commissioner of Police or the Authority, as the case may be.

subsection.leadIn: Where any equipment or commodity has been seized under subsection (1) and a claim is made in respect of the equipment or commodity within 48 hours after the date of the seizure, the Commissioner of Police or the Authority, as the case may be, unless an information is laid within 72 hours after the date of the seizure for a hawker offence in respect of the equipment or commodity, shall, if satisfied that the claimant was entitled to the possession of the equipment or commodity at the time of the seizure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: return the equipment or commodity to the claimant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a perishable commodity disposed of under subsection (2), assess its value and pay to him the amount of that value.

subsection.content: Where a claim under subsection (3) is refused, the claimant shall be informed of his rights under section 86C.

Where an information is laid within 72 hours after the date of seizure for an offence in respect of any equipment or commodity seized under subsection (1), the equipment or commodity, or, in the case of a perishable commodity that has been disposed of under subsection (2) by way of sale, the proceeds of sale, shall be retained pending disposal under section 86A.

section.name: s86A
section.heading: Forfeiture of hawker equipment and commodities by the court

subsection.leadIn: Where any person is convicted of a hawker offence in respect of any equipment or commodity seized under section 86(1), the informant shall inform the court of the seizure and thereupon the court shall, in addition to any other penalty—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the forfeiture of the equipment or commodity, or, in the case of a perishable commodity disposed of under section 86(2) by way of sale, the proceeds of sale, if the offence is one designated for the purposes of this subsection by regulations made under section 83A; or (Amended L.N. 244 of 1972)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless it finds and specifies special reasons, which reasons shall be special to the facts of the case and not special to the offender as distinct from the offence, shall, in the case of any other hawker offence, make such an order.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is charged with a hawker offence in respect of any equipment or commodity seized under section 86(1) is acquitted; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the hearing of any such charge the court finds special reasons under subsection (1)(b) of this section,

subsection.continued: the court shall, if it is satisfied that the person was lawfully entitled to possession of the equipment or commodity at the time of the seizure, order that it be returned to him or, in the case of a perishable commodity disposed of under section 86(2), assess the value of the commodity and order that the amount of that value be paid to him.

subsection.content: If the court is not so satisfied, it may, on the application of any other person claiming to be entitled to the equipment or commodity or of its own motion, make such other order as it thinks fit disposing of the equipment or commodity, or, in the case of a perishable commodity disposed of by way of sale, the proceeds of sale.

section.name: s86B
section.heading: Seizure of abandoned hawker equipment and commodities

subsection.content: A public officer authorized in writing by the Authority for the purposes of this section or a police officer may seize any equipment or commodity found in a public place which he has reason to believe has been abandoned by a hawker in circumstances not appearing to him to involve the commission of a hawker offence, and may cause such equipment or commodity to be removed to and kept at the risk of its owner at a Government depot or police station, or any other place approved by the Authority, pending its disposal under this Part. (Amended 28 of 1973 s. 4)
Any commodity of a perishable nature seized under subsection (1) may immediately be disposed of by the Commissioner of Police or the Authority, as the case may be.

subsection.leadIn: Where any equipment or commodity has been seized under subsection (1) and a claim is made in respect of the equipment or commodity within 48 hours after the date of the seizure, the Commissioner of Police or the Authority, as the case may be, shall, if satisfied that the claimant was entitled to the possession of the equipment or commodity at the time of the seizure and was not guilty of an offence in respect of it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: return the equipment or commodity to the claimant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a perishable commodity disposed of under subsection (2), assess its value and pay to him the amount of that value.

subsection.content: Where a claim under subsection (3) is refused, the claimant shall be informed of his rights under section 86C.

section.name: s86C
section.heading: Application to court for return of seized hawker equipment or commodities

subsection.leadIn: Where a claim in respect of any equipment or commodity is made under section 86 or 86B within the permitted time and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the claim is refused; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the claimant is dissatisfied with the amount of any payment made to him under either of those sections,

subsection.continued: an application may be made within 14 days of the refusal or payment to a court for an order for the return of the equipment or commodity or, in the case of a commodity disposed of under section 86(2) or 86B(2), for an assessment of the value of the commodity and for an order for the payment of the amount of that value or, as the case may be, the difference between the amount already paid and the amount of the value.

subsection.leadIn: Where an application is made under subsection (1), the court may, after first having given the person refusing the claim under section 86 or 86B an opportunity of being heard, make the order sought if it is satisfied that the applicant at the time of the seizure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was entitled to possession of the equipment or commodity; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: intended using the equipment or commodity for a lawful purpose.

subsection.content: If the court makes the order sought, it may award to the applicant such sum against the Government by way of costs as it thinks fair and reasonable. (Amended 59 of 2000 s. 3)

If the court does not make the order sought, it may, of its own motion, make such other order as it thinks fit disposing of the equipment or commodity, or, in the case of a perishable commodity disposed of by way of sale, the proceeds of sale.

section.name: s86D
section.heading: Forfeiture by operation of law
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no claim is made under section 86 or 86B in respect of any equipment or commodity seized under either of those sections within 48 hours after the date of the seizure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such a claim having been made and refused, no application is made under section 86C(1) in respect of the equipment or commodity within 14 days after the date of refusal,

section.continued: the equipment or commodity, or, in the case of a perishable commodity that has been disposed of under section 86(2) or 86B(2) by way of sale, the proceeds of sale, shall, unless the equipment or commodity has previously been returned to the person lawfully entitled to possession thereof or retained for disposal by the court under section 86A, be deemed on the expiry of the period of 48 hours or 14 days, as the case may be, to be forfeited to the Government.

section.name: s86E
section.heading: Interpretation for Part VIA

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: public place (公眾地方) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Summary Offences Ordinance (Cap. 228);
shop (店鋪) means any premises used for carrying on a business.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, a reference to an article includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any stock in trade, whether living or non-living; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other substance.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, a reference to a person concerned in a business carried on in a shop is a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person carrying on a business in the shop; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who has or appears to have control or management of the shop.

section.name: s86F
section.heading: Offence of shopfront extension
section.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person, without lawful authority or reasonable excuse—

subparagraph.content: places or otherwise leaves any article in a public place; or
causes, suffers or permits any article to be placed or otherwise left in a public place,

paragraph.continued: for the purpose of, in the course of or otherwise in connection with, the carrying on of a business in a shop; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the article so placed or left causes or may cause obstruction, inconvenience or danger to the public.

section.name: s86G
section.heading: Removal of articles constituting unlawful shopfront extensions

subsection.leadIn: If a public officer authorized under subsection (6) has reason to believe that an offence is being committed or has been committed under section 86F in respect of a business carried on in a shop, the officer may require—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person concerned in the business; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is apparently an employee or agent of the person mentioned in paragraph (a),

subsection.continued: to remove the article concerned from the public place within a period specified by the officer.

subsection.leadIn: In either of the following situations, the Authority may remove, seize or detain the article concerned—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a requirement made under subsection (1) is not complied with in respect of the article;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no person to whom the requirement may be made is present.

subsection.content: No claim may be made against the Authority or the Government, or against any person acting for or on behalf of the Authority or the Government, in respect of any loss or damage arising out of the removal, seizure or detention of an article, in good faith, under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The cost of the removal, seizure or detention of an article under subsection (2) may be recovered from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an owner of the article; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person who is concerned in the business,

subsection.continued: as a civil debt due to the Government.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (4), if the person from whom the cost may be recovered under that subsection consists of 2 or more persons, all of them are jointly and severally liable for the cost.
The Authority may in writing authorize a public officer for the purposes of subsection (1).

section.name: s86H
section.heading: Disposal etc. of articles removed, seized or detained

subsection.leadIn: If a power under section 86G(2) has been exercised in respect of an article, the Authority may forfeit the article to the Government so long as no claim is made for its return—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the article is not of a perishable nature—within 7 days after the date of the exercise of the power under that section; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the article is of a perishable nature—within 48 hours after the exercise of the power under that section.

subsection.content: If any article has been seized under section 86G(2) and a person (claimant) makes a claim in respect of the article within the period specified in subsection (1)(a) or (b) (whichever is applicable), the Authority is to, if satisfied that the claimant was entitled to the possession of the article at the time of the seizure, return the article to the claimant.

section.name: s92A
section.heading: Prohibition of certain activities without licence

subsection.content: No person shall conduct or open or keep open any place for the purpose of any activity specified in the Eleventh Schedule except under and in accordance with a licence issued by the Authority or a public officer authorized by the Authority for the purposes of this section. (Amended 53 of 1988 s. 4; 78 of 1999 s. 7)

subsection.def: For the purposes of subsection (1) place (地方), in relation to a billiard establishment, does not include premises used wholly for residential purposes and constituting a separate household unit to which only persons residing in the premises and their guests are admitted and where no fee is charged for the playing of billiards, snooker, pool or similar games. (Added 53 of 1988 s. 4)

section.name: s92AA
section.heading: Regulations providing for exemption from section 92A
section.content: The Authority may by regulation exempt any class or description of billiard establishment from the operation of section 92A.

section.name: s92AB
section.heading: Prohibition of any activity specified in Schedule 11A without licence
section.content: No person shall conduct, or open or keep open, any place for the purpose of any activity specified in Schedule 11A except under and in accordance with a licence issued by the Authority.

section.name: s92B
section.heading: Regulations relating to licensed activity
section.leadIn: The Authority may make regulations for any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the regulation and control of any activity or place in which any such activity specified in the Eleventh Schedule or Schedule 11A may be conducted; (Amended 78 of 1999 s. 7)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: classifying for the purposes of paragraph (a) any place or activity for which a licence may be issued;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the particulars which an applicant for any licence granted under this Part shall furnish;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the form and conditions of any licence granted under this Part, the hours during which the activity licensed may be conducted and the period for which such licence shall be issued; (Amended 49 of 1994 s. 22)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the lighting to be used in any place licensed under this Part and the general specifications and requirements to be satisfied in respect of such lighting, or to empower any specified officer to determine, at the time of the issue or renewal of any licence, the particular specifications and requirements to be satisfied in respect or such lighting in the place to which the licence relates;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: precautions to be taken against fire in any place licensed under this Part;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: maintenance of peace and good order in any place licensed under this Part;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: means of securing hygienic conditions and requiring the maintenance of such conditions in any place licensed under this Part;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: entry and inspection of any place licensed under this Part by any officer authorized by the Authority in that behalf.

section.name: s92C
section.heading: Offences

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any condition in a licence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in an application for a licence, furnishes any information which he knows or has reason to believe to be false in any material particular or by reason of the omission of any material particular or furnishes any information without any belief in the truth or accuracy of the information supplied,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence. (Amended 9 of 1976 s. 9)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes section 92A or 92AB shall be guilty of an offence. (Added 9 of 1976 s. 9. Amended 78 of 1999 s. 7)

section.name: s92D
section.heading: Liability of agents and servants
section.content: Whenever any person to whom any licence or permit or authority has been issued or granted under this Part would be liable to any punishment, penalty or forfeiture for any act, omission, neglect or default, he shall be liable to the same punishment, penalty or forfeiture for every similar act, omission, neglect or default of any agent or servant employed by him in the course of his business, and every such agent or servant shall also be liable to every punishment, penalty or forfeiture prescribed for such acts, omissions, neglects or defaults as fully and effectually as if he had been the person to whom the licence or permit or authority had been issued or granted.

section.name: s92E
section.heading: Saving
section.content: The provisions of this Part shall be in addition to and not in derogation of the provisions of any other enactment relating to or affecting any place, trade, business or occupation with respect to which this Part applies.

section.name: s93
section.heading: Power of Authority to require provision of ventilating system in scheduled premises

subsection.content: Save as provided in subsection (2) and section 101, where, in the opinion of the Authority, any scheduled premises do not have adequate natural ventilation, the Authority may, by notice in writing served on the owner or on the licensee of the scheduled premises, require such premises to be provided with a ventilating system which will provide for each person who may be accommodated in such premises an amount of outside air not less than that specified in the second column of the Second Schedule in respect of the class of premises to which such premises belong. (Amended 32 of 1963 s. 7)

Where, in the opinion of the Authority, a ventilating system which will provide an amount of air less than that prescribed in subsection (1) will, in conjunction with such natural ventilation as is available in any scheduled premises, adequately ventilate such premises, the Authority may, by notice in writing served on the owner or on the licensee of the scheduled premises, require such premises to be provided with a ventilating system which will provide for each person who may be accommodated in such premises such amount of outside air as may be specified in such notice. (Amended 32 of 1963 s. 7)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the provisions of any enactment under which such premises are licensed, the licensing authority may revoke the licence issued or granted by it in respect of any scheduled premises, either temporarily or permanently, in the following cases—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the event of any failure to comply with the requirements of a notice given in respect of such premises under the provisions of subsection (1) or (2) within 6 months from the date thereof or within such further period as the Authority may allow;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the event of any failure to comply with any conditions imposed under the provisions of section 101. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 5)

subsection.content: Any licensee or owner of any scheduled premises who fails to comply with the requirements of a notice under subsection (1) or (2) within 6 months from the date thereof, or within such further period as the Authority may allow, shall be guilty of an offence. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 5)

subsection.def: For the purposes of this Part, the expression licensing authority (發牌當局) means the public officer by whom any scheduled premises are, for the time being, licensed under the provisions of any enactment. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 5. Amended 78 of 1999 s. 7)

section.name: s94
section.heading: Certificate to be delivered to Authority in respect of new ventilating systems, and prohibition of alteration of ventilating system without permission

subsection.leadIn: Before any new ventilating system is installed in any scheduled premises, the licensee of the premises shall send to the Authority a certificate from the supplier of the ventilating system containing the following particulars in respect thereof—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the capacity of the fan in cubic metres per minute;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the outlet velocity of the fan in metres per minute;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the designed operating static pressure of the fan in pascals;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the speed of the fan pulley in revolutions per minute;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the net area of the air intake;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: except where the premises are air-conditioned with positive pressure, the net area of exhaust in square metres; and (Added 48 of 1969 s. 6)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the type of refrigerant (if any) to be used. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 6)

subsection.content: Save with the permission in writing of the Authority, no alteration shall be made to any ventilating system in any scheduled premises.
Any supplier who furnishes to the licensee of any such premises, for the purposes of this section, a certificate which is false or misleading shall be guilty of an offence. (Replaced 32 of 1963 s. 8)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Any licensee of any scheduled premises who contravenes the provisions of subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.content: Any licensee or owner of any scheduled premises who contravenes the provisions of subsection (2) shall be guilty of an offence. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3C
subsection.def: For the purposes of subsection (3B), owner (擁有人) includes any person in control of the scheduled premises whether as tenant thereof or under any licence from a tenant thereof. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 6)
In this section, supplier (供應商) means the importer or manufacturer of the ventilation system and his authorized agent. (Added 32 of 1963 s. 8)

section.name: s94A
section.heading: Regulations relating to ventilating systems in scheduled premises

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may make regulations for all or any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the regulation and control of ventilating systems in scheduled premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imposing requirements as to the design, construction, operation, maintenance and inspection of ventilating systems provided in scheduled premises.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the provisions of any enactment under which such premises are licensed, regulations made under this section may make provision for the revocation of any licence, issued or granted by a licensing authority in respect of scheduled premises, in the event of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contravention of any such regulation or of any condition imposed thereunder;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a failure to maintain any standard of safety or efficiency imposed or required thereunder.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Power of authorized officers to carry out tests
section.content: For the purposes of the provisions of this Part, any public officer authorized in writing in that behalf by the Authority and any officer of the Fire Services Department authorized in writing by the Director of Fire Services may carry out such tests of the ventilating system in any scheduled premises as may be necessary to ascertain whether or not the same is in safe and efficient working order.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Application of Part VIII to premises provided with ventilating systems at commencement of Ordinance, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where, at the commencement of this Ordinance, any scheduled premises are provided with a ventilating system, the provisions of section 93 and any regulations made under section 94A shall not apply to such premises unless and until—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of persons who may be accommodated in such premises is increased;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ventilating system is removed or is altered in any way; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Authority is of opinion that the ventilating system constitutes a danger to health or the Director of Fire Services considers it to be a fire hazard. (Amended 61 of 1974 s. 9)

subsection.content: Upon the application of section 93 and any regulations made under section 94A to any such premises, the Authority may, subject to such conditions as it may specify, grant such exemption from or such modifications of the provisions of this Part as it thinks fit. (Amended 61 of 1974 s. 9)
Any licensee or owner of any scheduled premises who fails to comply with any condition specified under subsection (2) shall be guilty of an offence. (Added 61 of 1974 s. 9)

section.name: s102
section.heading: Amendment of Second Schedule
section.text: The Chief Executive in Council may by order add any class of premises to, or delete any class of premises from, the Second Schedule, and may in like manner amend that Schedule.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Saving in relation to Buildings Ordinance
section.content: Nothing in this Part shall be taken or construed to the prejudice of the provisions of the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123).

section.name: s104
section.heading: Regulations for control of advertisements

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other enactment relating to advertisements, decorations or signs, the Authority may make regulations restricting, regulating or prohibiting the exhibition of advertisements, decorations or signs of any kind whatsoever, and, in particular, may make regulations restricting, regulating or prohibiting the exhibition thereof in such places or in such manner or by such means as, in the opinion of the Authority, may affect injuriously or disfigure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amenities of any place or locality;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the natural beauty of a landscape;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the view from any highway, railway, tramway, ferry or from any public place or water;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the amenities of any village; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the amenities of any historic or public building or monument or of any place frequented by the public solely or chiefly on account of its beauty or historic interest.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may, in addition to any penalties prescribed, provide for the removal and disposal of any advertisement, decoration or sign exhibited in contravention of any regulation made under subsection (1) and for the recovery of any expenses incurred thereby.

content.leadIn: Regulations made under this section may be of general application or may be restricted to certain areas or to certain types or classes of advertisements, decorations or signs:
content.proviso: Provided that, where the application of any such regulation is restricted to certain areas only, such areas shall be distinctly marked and shown on plans signed by or on behalf of the Authority and deposited in the offices of the Authority, and such plans shall at all reasonable times thereafter be open for inspection by the public without charge.

section.name: s104A
section.heading: Prohibition on display of bills or posters without permission

subsection.leadIn: No bill or poster shall be displayed or affixed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on any private land, except with the written permission of the owner or occupier thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on any Government land, except with the written permission of the Authority. (Amended 29 of 1998 s. 105)

subsection.content: A person displaying or affixing a bill or poster in contravention of subsection (1) commits an offence.

section.name: s104B
section.heading: Duty to maintain bill or poster in clean and tidy condition

subsection.content: Where a bill or poster is displayed on any private land or on any Government land, the bill or poster shall be maintained in a clean and tidy condition to the reasonable satisfaction of the Authority. (Amended 29 of 1998 s. 105)
A person displaying a bill or poster in contravention of subsection (1) commits an offence.

A person prosecuted for an offence under this section shall not be convicted of that offence unless prior to the commencement of the prosecution the Authority served on him a notice in writing informing him of the condition of the bill or poster and warning him that unless the bill or poster is removed within the period specified in the notice (being not less than 24 hours) he may be liable to be prosecuted.

section.name: s104C
section.heading: Power to remove bills and posters

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a bill or poster is displayed in contravention of section 104A(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a bill or poster is not maintained in a clean and tidy condition as required under section 104B(1),

subsection.continued: the Authority may remove the bill or poster and may recover the cost of removal from the person displaying the bill or poster as a civil debt.

subsection.content: Where any person is convicted of an offence under section 104A(1) or 104B(1) the court by whom that person is convicted may order him to pay, in addition to or in lieu of any penalty for which he is liable for that offence, the cost or estimated cost of removing the bill or poster in respect of which the offence was committed.

Where a bill or poster to which subsection (1)(a) or (b) applies is displayed on private land, nothing in this section shall derogate from any cause of action or remedy which the owner or occupier of that land may be able to enforce against the person who displays the bill or poster.

If a bill or poster to which subsection (1)(a) or (b) applies is displayed, the Authority’s power exercisable under subsection (1) includes the power to remove the display equipment for the bill or poster. (Added 13 of 2025 s. 7)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any display equipment is removed by virtue of subsection (4); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no claim is made, within 7 days after the date of the removal, for its return,

subsection.continued: the Authority may forfeit it to the Government and may dispose of it. (Added 13 of 2025 s. 7)

subsection.content: No claim may be made against the Authority or the Government, or against any person acting for or on behalf of the Authority or the Government, in respect of any loss or damage arising out of the removal of a bill, poster or display equipment, in good faith, under this section. (Added 13 of 2025 s. 7)

section.name: s104D
section.heading: Certain persons also deemed to display bills or posters

subsection.leadIn: Where a person commits an offence against section 104A(1) the following persons shall be guilty of that offence in the same manner and to the same extent as if they had personally committed it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any other person who uses the first-mentioned person to display or affix the bill or poster; and

content.leadIn: any person whose goods, trade, business or other concerns are given publicity by the bill or poster:

subsection.proviso: Provided that a person referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) shall not be guilty of an offence under section 104A(1) by reason only that he uses the person to display or affix the bill or poster or that his goods, trade, business or other concerns are given publicity by the bill or poster, if he proves that it was displayed or affixed without his knowledge or consent.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 104B and 104C a person shall be deemed to display a bill or poster if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the bill or poster is displayed on land of which he is the owner or occupier; or

content.leadIn: the bill or poster gives publicity to his goods, trade, business or other concerns:

subsection.proviso: Provided that a person shall not be guilty of an offence under section 104B or be liable for the cost of removal under section 104C by reason only that the bill or poster is displayed on land of which he is the owner or occupier, or that his goods, trade, business or other concerns are given publicity by the bill or poster, if he proves that it was displayed without his knowledge or consent.

section.name: s104E
section.heading: Definitions and saving for other enactments

def.name: Authority
def.leadIn: In sections 104A, 104B and 104C Authority (主管當局) means—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: during the Concession Period within the meaning of section 2(1) of the Mass Transit Railway Ordinance (Cap. 556) and in respect of any land belonging to the Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation which the MTR Corporation Limited has the right to have access to, use or possess during the Concession Period, the MTR Corporation Limited; (Replaced 11 of 2007 s. 36)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: at any time outside the Concession Period referred to in paragraph (b) and in respect of any land belonging to the Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation, the Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation; (Added 11 of 2007 s. 36)

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: in respect of any land within a country park or special area as defined in the Country Parks Ordinance (Cap. 208), the Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation; (Amended L.N. 331 of 1999)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: in respect of any public cargo working area as defined in the Port Control (Public Cargo Working Area) (Consolidation) Order (Cap. 81 sub. leg. B) and in respect of any land within the boundaries of any ferry terminal declared under regulation 3 of the Shipping and Port Control (Ferry Terminals) Regulations (Cap. 313 sub. leg. H), the Director of Marine; (Replaced 10 of 1986 s. 10. Amended 64 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: in respect of any land, whether private land or Government land, not being land referred to in paragraph (b), (c), (d) or (e), the Director of Food and Environmental Hygiene. (Replaced 78 of 1999 s. 7. Amended 23 of 2002 s. 86)

def.name: Land
def.leadIn: In sections 104A, 104B, 104C, 104D and in this section, land (土地) includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any building or other erection on land, whether a fixture or not;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any tree, rock or other natural part of land; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: land covered by water.

subsection.def: In sections 104A, 104C and 104D occupier (佔用人) means any lessee, principal tenant or other person having direct control of the land.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: In section 104C and in this section—
subsection.def: display equipment (展示設備), in relation to a bill or poster that is displayed, means any structure, apparatus or hoarding used for the display. (Added 13 of 2025 s. 8)

In this Part, bill or poster (招貼或海報) includes any word, letter, model, sign, placard, board, notice, device or representation and also includes any advertisement painted on any wall, fence, railing, post, rock, road-cutting or tree but does not include any display equipment for a bill or poster. (Amended 13 of 2025 s. 8)

subsection.content: Nothing in this Part, or in any permission granted under section 104A, shall operate so as to affect any obligation or liability imposed or incurred under any other enactment in relation to the display of any bill or poster.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Provisions as to dangerous advertisement hoardings

subsection.content: Where, in the opinion of the Authority, any hoarding, scaffolding or other structure erected solely for the purpose of exhibiting advertisements is dangerous, or is likely to become dangerous, by reason of its construction, wind, rain, dilapidation, its age or other cause, the Authority shall cause a notice to be served upon the owner of such hoarding, scaffolding or other structure, or upon his servant or agent, requiring him, within such reasonable period as shall be specified in the notice, to remove such hoarding, scaffolding or other structure or to do such work as may be specified in the notice to render the same safe. (Replaced 11 of 1989 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: If the person upon whom a notice is served under the provisions of subsection (1) fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof, within the time specified therein—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such person shall be guilty of an offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority may execute, or cause to be executed, any work necessary to satisfy the requirements of the notice, and dispose of any materials removed in executing any such work, and may recover any expenses incurred thereby from such person. (Amended 11 of 1989 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of any such hoarding, scaffolding or other structure, or his servant or agent is not known or cannot be readily found; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such hoarding, scaffolding or other structure is, in the opinion of the Authority, in such a state that it ought immediately to be removed or rendered safe,

subsection.continued: the Authority may forthwith, whether or not a notice has been served under subsection (1), remove it or render it safe. (Replaced 11 of 1989 s. 2)

subsection.content: Where any hoarding, scaffolding or structure is removed by the Authority under the provisions of subsection (3), the Authority may dispose of any materials so removed and may recover any expenses incurred in the removal of the hoarding, scaffolding or structure and in the disposal of the materials from the owner or such hoarding, scaffolding or structure or, where the owner thereof is unknown to, or cannot be readily found or ascertained by the Authority or is absent from Hong Kong, the Authority may sell the materials and, after deducting from the proceeds of such sale such expenses, shall pay the surplus, if any, into the Treasury. (Amended 71 of 1971 s. 3; 10 of 1986 s. 24; 11 of 1989 s. 2)

Any money paid into the Treasury in pursuance of subsection (4) which remains unclaimed for a period of 5 years shall be transferred to the general revenue of Hong Kong. (Added 71 of 1971 s. 3. Amended 10 of 1986 s. 24)

section.name: s105A
section.heading: Provision for stadia

subsection.content: The Authority may by order published in the Gazette set aside any premises for use as a stadium.
The premises specified in the Twelfth Schedule shall be deemed to have been set aside under subsection (1) for use as a stadium.
The Authority shall, as soon as practicable, arrange for the preparation by the Director of Buildings and Lands of a plan of every stadium. (Amended L.N. 76 of 1982; L.N. 94 of 1986)
Every plan prepared in accordance with subsection (3) shall be deposited in the Land Registry. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 2; 20 of 2002 s. 5)
The Authority may, by order published in the Gazette, amend, add to or delete from, the Twelfth Schedule.

section.name: s105B
section.heading: Management of stadia

subsection.content: Subject to section 105F, the management and control of any stadium and the right to provide therein facilities of any kind shall be vested in the Authority.
The Authority may enter into contracts for the purpose of the management of any stadium and the provision of facilities therein.
The Authority may specify the purposes for which any stadium, or any part thereof, may be used.

section.name: s105C
section.heading: Allocation and granting of stadium or parts thereof

subsection.content: The Authority may grant to any person the exclusive use of any stadium or any part thereof for such purposes and at such times as the Authority may approve in each case.

subsection.leadIn: The person to whom the exclusive use of any stadium has been granted under subsection (1) shall determine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not the public shall be admitted to the stadium during the period of such exclusive use; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fees, if any, to be paid by members of the public for admission during this period.

section.name: s105D
section.heading: Regulations relating to stadia
section.leadIn: The Authority may make regulations for any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the management and control, including the closing or partial closing, of any stadium;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fixing of the times during which any stadium, or any part thereof, may be open to members of the public;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the preservation of good order and discipline and prevention of nuisance in any stadium;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the control (including prohibition) of trading, advertising or the erection of structures in any stadium; the removal, storage and sale of any trading, advertising or construction materials that are brought into or remain in a stadium in contravention of any regulations made under this section; the recovery of any costs incurred in respect of such removal, storage and sale; and the forfeiture of the proceeds of sale. (Replaced 45 of 1981 s. 2)

section.name: s105E
section.heading: Authority may specify conditions for the use of stadia, etc.
section.leadIn: The Authority may specify the conditions to be observed in the use of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a stadium;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a part of a stadium; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any facilities provided in a stadium or part of a stadium.

section.name: s105G
section.heading: Provision for museums
section.content: The Authority may, by order published in the Gazette, designate any building, or part of a building, or area as a museum.

section.name: s105H
section.heading: Management of museums

subsection.content: The management and control of every museum and the right to provide therein facilities of any kind shall be vested in the Authority.
The Authority may enter into contracts for the purpose of the management of any museum and the provision of facilities therein.
The Authority may specify the purposes for which any museum, or any part thereof, may be used.

section.name: s105I
section.heading: Regulations relating to museums
section.leadIn: The Authority may make regulations for any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fixing of days and hours during which the public may be admitted to a museum, or any part thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the closing or partial closing of a museum;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the regulation of admission of any person, animal, bird, fish or thing to a museum, or any part thereof; (Amended 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the regulation of the borrowing, copying, photographing or reproduction of exhibits; (Amended 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the regulation of the use of any exhibit or facility in a museum;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the regulation of the conduct of persons and the prevention of nuisances in a museum; (Amended 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the protection of a museum and the exhibits, fittings and furniture therein, and any other contents thereof, from damage, destruction or loss;

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.leadIn: the assessment and recovery of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the amount to be paid by way of compensation for any damage or loss sustained by the Government by reason of the fact that any part of, or any fitting, furniture or other thing in, a museum, or any exhibit, has been damaged, destroyed or lost; and (Amended 10 of 1986 s. 12; 78 of 1999 s. 7)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a surcharge not exceeding 20% of such amount; (Added 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which a person may be refused the use of any facility in a museum; (Amended 78 of 1999 s. 7)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the circumstances under which any person may be refused entry into a museum or directed to leave a museum, or any part thereof; (Amended 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the terms and conditions under which any article may be brought into or used within a museum;

paragraph.name: ja
paragraph.content: the terms and conditions under which articles may be deposited in a museum for safe-keeping whilst any person is in the museum; (Added 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the control of the movement and parking of vehicles within a museum;

paragraph.name: ka
paragraph.content: the control (including prohibition) of trading, advertising, the bringing of display material or the erection of structures in any museum; the removal, storage and sale of any trading, advertising, display or construction materials that are brought into or remain in a museum in contravention of any regulations made under this section; the recovery of any costs incurred in respect of such removal, storage and sale; and the forfeiture of the proceeds of sale; (Added 66 of 1982 s. 3)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: the prevention of obstruction of the staff of a museum in the performance of their duties;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: appeal against any decision, direction or requirement made or given by a public officer in accordance with regulations made under this section;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: the general regulation and management of a museum.

section.name: s105K
section.heading: Provision for and management of libraries

subsection.content: The Authority may, by order published in the Gazette, designate any building, or part of a building, as a library. (Amended 9 of 1976 s. 10)
The management and control of every library shall be vested in the Authority.
The Authority may establish and maintain mobile libraries for the use of the public.

The Authority may set aside and use any part of a library for the purposes of study or research, the holding of classes or exhibitions, the viewing or hearing of library material, or for other like purposes of an educational or cultural nature, and in connection therewith may provide the requisite equipment and facilities. (Added 50 of 1979 s. 3)

section.name: s105L
section.heading: Regulations relating to libraries

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may make regulations for any of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribing the powers, duties and functions of the librarian;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fixing the hours during which any library shall be open to the public;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: regulating admission to any library or any part thereof or the use of any library or any part thereof or any of the equipment, facilities or library material provided in any library;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: regulating the lending and borrowing of library material in any library;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: requiring a guarantee or security to be given by any person borrowing library material from a library;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: regulating the conduct of persons in any library;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: protecting any library and the fittings, furniture, equipment and library material therein, and any other contents thereof, from damage;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: providing for the assessment and recovery of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the amount to be paid by way of compensation for the loss or damage sustained by the Government by reason of the fact that any fitting, furniture, equipment or library material has been lost, damaged or destroyed; and (Amended 10 of 1986 s. 13; 78 of 1999 s. 7)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a surcharge not exceeding 20% of such amount;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: enabling any person to be refused the use of any library or any of the equipment, facilities or library material in any library and the removal from a library of any person;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: stipulating the terms on which articles may be deposited in a library for safe-keeping whilst any person is in the library;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: providing for the penalties to be paid by any person in respect of the borrowing of library material from any library, the use or reservation of library material in any library, the deposit of articles in a library for safe-keeping and the use of rooms, equipment or facilities provided in any part of any library; (Amended 49 of 1994 s. 24)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: providing for the general regulation and management of any library.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be taken to authorize the infringement of copyright in any library material.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section and any regulations made hereunder, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression library (圖書館) includes a mobile library.

section.name: s105M
section.heading: Provision for civic centres

subsection.content: The Authority may, by order published in the Gazette, set aside any premises and the grounds appurtenant thereto for use as a civic centre.
The premises specified in the Thirteenth Schedule shall be deemed to have been set aside under subsection (1) for use as a civic centre.

The Authority shall, as soon as practicable, arrange for the preparation by the Director of Buildings and Lands of a plan of every civic centre and the grounds appurtenant thereto. (Amended L.N. 76 of 1982; L.N. 94 of 1986)
Every plan prepared in accordance with subsection (3) shall be deposited in the Land Registry. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 2; 20 of 2002 s. 5)
The Authority may, by order published in the Gazette, amend, add to or delete from, the Thirteenth Schedule.

section.name: s105N
section.heading: Management of civic centres

subsection.content: The management and control of every civic centre and the right to provide therein facilities of any kind shall be vested in the Authority.
The Authority may enter into contracts for the purpose of the management of any civic centre and the provision of facilities therein.
The Authority may specify the purposes for which any civic centre, or any part thereof, may be used.

section.name: s105O
section.heading: Regulations relating to civic centres
section.leadIn: The Authority may make regulations for any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fixing of the days of the week and the hours of the day during which any civic centre or any part thereof may be open to members of the public;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the regulation of the conduct of persons admitted to any civic centre or any part thereof and for the removal therefrom of any person who infringes any of the provisions of any regulation made pursuant to this section;

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: the control (including prohibition) of trading, advertising or the erection of structures in any civic centre; the removal, storage and sale of any trading, advertising or construction materials that are brought into or remain in a civic centre in contravention of any regulations made under this section; the recovery of any costs incurred in respect of such removal, storage and sale; and the forfeiture of the proceeds of sale; (Added 45 of 1981 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the general regulation and management of civic centres and any facilities provided therein.

section.name: s105P
section.heading: Authority may specify conditions for the use of civic centres, etc.
section.leadIn: The Authority may specify the conditions to be observed in the use of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a civic centre;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a part of a civic centre; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any facilities provided in a civic centre or part of a civic centre.

section.name: s105Q
section.heading: Grant of use of civic centres
section.content: Notwithstanding any power to make regulations under section 105O or to specify conditions conferred by section 105P, the Authority may grant, either gratuitously or for payment, to any person the exclusive use of any part of a civic centre for such period or periods and for such purposes as the Authority may consider fit in each case; and admission by the public to any such part, the exclusive use of which has been so granted, shall be either with or without payment as may be directed either by the Authority or, with the consent of the Authority, by the person to whom the use thereof has been so granted.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Provision of public pleasure grounds

subsection.content: The Authority may, from time to time, by order set aside places for use as public pleasure grounds, and may by the same or any subsequent order specify the purpose for which such grounds or any part thereof shall be used.
The places specified in the Fourth Schedule shall be deemed to have been set aside under the provisions of subsection (1) for use as public pleasure grounds.
The Authority shall, as soon as practicable, prepare a plan of every public pleasure ground.

Where the boundaries of any public pleasure ground are so varied, or such pleasure ground is otherwise so changed, as to render any plan deposited in accordance with the provisions of subsection (5) no longer accurate, the Authority shall withdraw the plan so deposited and shall, as soon as practicable, prepare an amended plan or a new plan of such pleasure ground.
Every plan prepared in accordance with the provisions of subsection (3) or (4) shall be deposited in the Land Registry. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 2; 20 of 2002 s. 5)
The Authority may by order amend, or add to or delete from, the Fourth Schedule.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Management and control of public pleasure grounds

subsection.content: The general management and control of public pleasure grounds, including the exclusive right to provide amenities of any kind, shall be vested in the Authority.

The Authority may provide and demarcate public pleasure grounds for the conduct of games, sports and leisure activities and make such provision for other facilities for physical and other recreation as it may consider fit. (Amended 78 of 1999 s. 7)

Subject to the provisions of section 106(1) and of subsection (4) the Authority may, from time to time, specify the purpose for which any public pleasure ground or any part of any such ground may be used, whether for the provision of facilities for physical or other recreation or otherwise.

The Chief Executive, where he considers it necessary or desirable, may require the Authority to refrain from using, or permitting the use of, any public pleasure grounds or any part of any public pleasure grounds for any purposes which may have been specified by it under the provisions of subsection (3). (Amended 59 of 2000 s. 3)

section.name: s108
section.heading: Temporary closure of public pleasure grounds, etc.

subsection.content: The Authority may, from time to time and for any purpose, temporarily close to the public the whole or any part of any public pleasure ground.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may, on the application of any school, club or association or of any individual person, allocate to the same, either gratuitously or on payment of a fee and on such days or for such periods as may be specified, the exclusive use of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any playing field or playing pitch demarcated under the provisions of section 107 for the conduct of organized games and sports;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any tennis court in any public pleasure ground, any facilities provided under the provisions of section 107 for physical or other recreation or any other part of any public pleasure ground, other than a playing field or playing pitch demarcated under the provisions of that section for the conduct of organized games and sports.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Regulations relating to public pleasure grounds
section.leadIn: The Authority may in relation to public pleasure grounds, make regulations prescribing or providing for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proper management and control, including closure or partial closure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: preservation of good order and prevention of abuses and nuisances;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the control (including prohibition) of building, trading or advertising;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the control (including prohibition) of fishing at any beach;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the control (including prohibition) of the use of vessels, boats or other means of water transport, including water-skis and models, at any beach;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the seizure and disposal of any vehicle, vessel, animal or other article or thing in respect of which any regulation made under this section is contravened.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Public pleasure ground rules

subsection.content: The Authority may, in relation to a public pleasure ground, make rules which are not inconsistent with regulations made under section 109 to provide for the better control of persons in connection with the use of the public pleasure ground and to provide information relating to the use of the public pleasure ground. (Replaced 78 of 1999 s. 7)
Any person who fails to comply with any rule made under the provisions of subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Appointment and powers of keepers

subsection.content: The Authority may appoint keepers for public pleasure grounds.

Where any person is found by a keeper of any public pleasure ground to be contravening the provisions of any regulation, rule or order relating to such public pleasure ground, such keeper may arrest such person and deliver him into the custody of a police officer or take him to the nearest police station, whereupon the provisions of sections 51 and 52 of the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232) or of section 52 of that Ordinance, as the case may be, shall apply.

section.name: s111A
section.heading: Interpretation of this Part
section.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: private street (私家街道) means a street on land held under Government lease, licence or otherwise from the Government or on land over which the Government has granted or reserved a right of way; (Amended 29 of 1998 s. 105)
street (街道) includes a private street and any area of land declared to be a street by the Director of Highways. (Amended L.N. 76 of 1982; L.N. 127 of 1986)

section.name: s111B
section.heading: Proposal of private street name

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), a person may propose—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a name of a private street that has not been named; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a change of name of a private street that has been named,

subsection.continued: by notice in writing sent to the Authority.

subsection.content: No person other than the owner of the land that is held under or by virtue of a Government lease and on which the private street is situated may make a proposal under subsection (1) in connection with that private street. (Amended 29 of 1998 s. 105)

subsection.leadIn: The Authority shall, after the receipt of a proposal under subsection (1), consider the application and shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make a declaration under section 111C(1)(a) or (b), as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to make a declaration.

subsection.content: Where the Authority under subsection (3) has refused to make a declaration, the Authority shall serve notice of its decision, setting out reasons for its decision, upon the person who made application under subsection (1).

A person on whom a notice under subsection (4) is served may, within 30 days of the date of the notice, appeal to the Municipal Services Appeals Board against the decision of the Authority. (Replaced 78 of 1999 s. 7)

section.name: s111C
section.heading: Declaration of street name

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding section 111B, the Authority, by declaration in the Gazette, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: assign a name to a street that has not been named; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: change the name of a street that has been named.

subsection.content: The Authority shall, not less than 30 days prior to a declaration under subsection (1)(b), give notice of its intention to change the street name.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (2) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contain a brief description of the proposal to change the street name;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify an address for service of objections to the proposal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the time within which objections may be lodged; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: be published—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the Gazette; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by posting it in both the English and Chinese languages in a prominent place in or near the street or part of the street which will be affected by the proposed declaration.

subsection.content: A person may, within 30 days of the date of publication in the Gazette of the notice under subsection (2), object, in writing to the Authority, against the proposed declaration under subsection (1)(b).

The Authority shall consider an objection under subsection (4) and shall, before a declaration is made under subsection (1)(b), serve notice of its decision, setting out reasons for its decision, upon the person who made an objection.

A person on whom a notice under subsection (5) is served may, within 30 days of the date of the notice, appeal to the Municipal Services Appeals Board against the decision of the Authority. (Replaced 78 of 1999 s. 7)

section.name: s111D
section.heading: Penalty for marking or displaying other street name
section.content: Where the Authority has declared a street name under section 111C(1), any person who marks or displays any other street name other than that street name so declared on a building or erection in the street commits an offence.

section.name: s112
section.heading: Restriction upon the keeping of dead bodies in domestic premises

subsection.content: Any person who keeps, or causes or permits to be kept, for a longer period than 48 hours the dead body of any person in premises used for the purpose of human habitation shall, unless such dead body is encoffined in a hermetically sealed coffin, be guilty of an offence.

Any person who, without the permission in writing of the Authority, keeps, or causes or permits to be kept, for a longer period than 7 days (inclusive of the period of 48 hours referred to in subsection (1)) any encoffined dead body, notwithstanding that the coffin be hermetically sealed, in any premises used for the purpose of human habitation shall be guilty of an offence.

section.name: s112A
section.heading: Authority may order human remains to be buried or cremated

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to the provisions of section 16(1) of the Births and Deaths Registration Ordinance (Cap. 174), cause a notice in the form of Form E specified in the Seventh Schedule to be served on a person who has the right to effect the disposal of any human remains, requiring him to cause them to be lawfully buried or cremated within such period as may be specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the human remains referred to in the notice are not lawfully buried or cremated within the period specified in the notice, take possession of the human remains and arrange for their disposal in any manner it may think fit.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may take possession of any human remains and arrange for their disposal in any manner it may think fit, if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no person who has the right to dispose of the human remains is in Hong Kong or can be readily ascertained or found; or (Amended 10 of 1986 s. 24)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every person who has the right to dispose of the human remains is under disability.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with a notice served on him under subsection (1)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the expiration of any period specified in a notice under subsection (1)(a), has in his possession without the written permission of the Authority any human remains to which the notice relates,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section, human remains (人類遺骸) does not include skeletal remains.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall derogate from any provision in any enactment which permits the use of any human remains or the removal and use of part of any human remains for therapeutic purposes or for purposes of medical education or research.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Public and private cemeteries

subsection.content: The places specified in Part 1 of the Fifth Schedule shall be places set apart for use as public cemeteries. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 157)
The places specified in Part 2 of the Fifth Schedule shall be places set apart for use as private cemeteries. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 157)

subsection.name: 2AA
subsection.content: A columbarium, as defined by section 113A(1), that is under the management and control of a person specified in Part 2A of the Fifth Schedule is a private cemetery. (Added 8 of 2017 s. 124)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The places specified in Part 4A of the Fifth Schedule shall be places set apart for use by The Commonwealth War Graves Commission as Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemeteries. (Added 69 of 1976 s. 2. Amended 12 of 1994 s. 3)
The Chief Executive in Council may by order amend, or add any cemetery to or delete any cemetery from, the Fifth Schedule (except its Part 2A). (Amended 59 of 2000 s. 3; 8 of 2017 s. 124)
The Chief Executive in Council may by order amend, or add a person to, or delete a person from, Part 2A of the Fifth Schedule. (Added 8 of 2017 s. 124)

section.name: s113A
section.heading: Columbarium managed and controlled by person specified in Part 2A of Fifth Schedule

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: ashes (骨灰) has the same meaning as it has in section 2(1) of the Private Columbaria Ordinance (Cap. 630); (Amended E.R. 4 of 2017)
columbarium (骨灰安置所), subject to subsection (6), has the same meaning as it has in section 2(1) of the Private Columbaria Ordinance (Cap. 630); (Amended E.R. 4 of 2017)
inter (安放) has the same meaning as it has in section 2(1) of the Private Columbaria Ordinance (Cap. 630); (Amended E.R. 4 of 2017)
interment right (安放權) has the same meaning as it has in section 2(1) of the Private Columbaria Ordinance (Cap. 630); (Amended E.R. 4 of 2017)
specified person (指明人士) means a person specified in Part 2A of the Fifth Schedule.

subsection.leadIn: No ashes may be interred in a columbarium that is under the management and control of a specified person, nor may an interment right in respect of the columbarium be sold, unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the specified person has provided to the Authority information on the name and location of the columbarium; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 6 months have lapsed since the information was so provided.

subsection.content: The Authority must, by notice in the Gazette, publish the information within 3 months after receiving it.
The notice is not subsidiary legislation.

A specified person must provide to the Authority, on request, a list setting out the name, location and other particulars of each columbarium that is under the specified person’s management and control.
This section does not apply to a columbarium in a private cemetery specified in Part 2 of the Fifth Schedule.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Plans and demarcations of cemeteries

subsection.content: The Authority shall, as soon as practicable, prepare a plan of every cemetery and mark the boundaries thereof in such manner as it may think fit.

Subject to subsection (2A), where the boundaries of any cemetery are so varied, or any cemetery is otherwise so changed, as to render any plan deposited in accordance with the provisions of subsection (3) no longer accurate, the Authority shall withdraw the plan so deposited and shall, as soon as practicable, prepare an amended plan or a new plan of such cemetery and, where necessary, further mark the boundaries thereof in such manner as it may think fit. (Amended 12 of 1994 s. 4)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The Authority shall, before exercising any power conferred on it under subsection (2) in relation to a Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery, consult with The Commonwealth War Graves Commission. (Added 12 of 1994 s. 4)
Every plan prepared in accordance with the provisions of subsection (1) or (2) shall be deposited in the Land Registry. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 2; 20 of 2002 s. 5)

section.name: s115
section.heading: General management and closure of public cemeteries and Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemeteries

subsection.content: The general management and control of public cemeteries shall be vested in the Authority. (Amended 69 of 1976 s. 3; 12 of 1994 s. 5)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The general management and control of Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemeteries shall be vested in The Commonwealth War Graves Commission. (Added 12 of 1994 s. 5)
The Authority may by notification in the Gazette declare any public cemetery, or any part of such a cemetery, to be closed. (Replaced 69 of 1976 s. 3. Amended 12 of 1994 s. 5)

Any person who buries, or causes or permits to be buried, any human remains, or deposits, or causes or permits to be deposited, any urn containing any human remains, in any cemetery or any part of any cemetery which has been declared to be closed under the provisions of subsection (2) shall be guilty of an offence.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Regulations relating to cemeteries

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything contained in any deed of appropriation, deed of grant or other instrument relating to any cemetery, the Authority may make regulations prescribing or providing for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the marking or otherwise identifying of graves, vaults and urns, and the provision, custody, maintenance and inspection of registers of burials therein;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the control of the number of dead bodies which may be buried in any one grave or vault;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the interspace between graves and between vaults;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the manner of closing, turfing or covering of graves, the materials to be used therefor and the period within which any grave must be so closed, turfed or covered;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the re-opening of graves and vaults and the removal of human remains therefrom;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the prevention and abatement of nuisances in connection with any cemetery, grave, vault, urn or the burial of any human remains;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the entry and inspection of cemeteries and vaults;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the proper management of cemeteries;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the depth and size of graves and vaults;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: such other matters as, in the opinion of the Authority, are necessary for the proper regulation and control of cemeteries in the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: In addition to the purposes specified in subsection (1), the Authority may in relation to any public cemetery make regulations prescribing or providing for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the lay-out and use of any such cemetery or any part thereof and matters ancillary thereto;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the exhumation of human remains from any grave and the disposal of the same in a decent manner;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the size of any monument or enclosure over or round any grave, vault or urn;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the orderly and decent conduct of any burial, exhumation or removal of any human remains and the performance of any ceremony, rite, custom or religious practice connected therewith in any such cemetery or in any part of any such cemetery and the orderly and decent conduct of persons resorting to any such cemetery. (Amended 49 of 1994 s. 28)

subsection.content: Regulations made under subsection (1) shall not apply in relation to any Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery. (Added 12 of 1994 s. 6)

section.name: s117
section.heading: Public cemetery and Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery rules

subsection.content: The Authority may, in relation to a public cemetery or Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery, make rules which are not inconsistent with regulations made under section 116 to provide for the better control of persons in connection with the use of the cemetery or Cemetery and to provide information relating to the use of the cemetery or Cemetery. (Replaced 78 of 1999 s. 7)
Any person who fails to comply with any rule made under subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Prohibition of unauthorized burials and exhumations

subsection.content: Any person who, without the permission in writing of the Authority, buries any human remains, or deposits any urn or other receptacle containing any human remains, or scatters the ashes of any human remains after cremation, otherwise than in a cemetery, shall be guilty of an offence.
